Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Evolution of visual pigments in fireflies (Coleoptera: Lampyridae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
How and why new mating signals arise and spread through a population remain open questions in evolutionary biology. However, it has been difficult to study signaling traits from a genetic perspective since signals, and the receptors that enable their detection, are often complex physical and/or behavioral traits affected by many genes. Fireflies offer an ideal system to study signal evolution because of their conspicuous and highly variable mating signals. These include lighted signals that range from simple glows to complex flashes, and differ in color, from blue/green to orange. Importantly, the underlying genetic basis of the lighted signal and signal receptor are both simple: light production is controlled by a single enzyme (luciferase) and visual receptor sensitivity by a single family of receptors (opsins). This work will use Next Generation sequencing techniques to examine the evolution of opsins in relationship to signal color and environmental light conditions.

This work will offer an unprecedented look at the evolution of visual receptors in a nocturnal visual signaling system. Combined with ongoing work examining the evolution of the light signal, it will allow testing of hypotheses for the molecular evolution of genes underlying both signals and receptors. It will revolutionize the genetic resources for fireflies and has the potential to place fireflies at the forefront of signal evolution research. Research opportunities will be offered for undergraduate students and resources developed for K-9 education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant facilitated collection and sequencing of fireflies from over 50 field sites throughout the Eastern United States. At each location, the time of activity, habitat characteristics, and the color of males’ emitted light were measured. In addition, specimens were used for DNA or RNA extraction. These data allowed the evolution of a major component of the visual reception system to be determined. There were several important findings:

 

North American fireflies have only two proteins (opsins) that make up visual pigments. One of these proteins is clearly a member of a group of opsins that are usually for the detection of long wavelengths of light (green). The other is clearly a member of a group of opsins that detect ultraviolet wavelengths. The finding of only two opsins, which was confirmed using several lines of evidence, is an unexpected result—fireflies lack an opsin from the blue opsin group, but it has previously been shown that the firefly eye is sensitive to these wavelengths. This finding implies that fireflies use either the long wavelength (most likely) or ultraviolet opsin to detect blue light.

 

A change from nocturnal to diurnal activity is associated with strong selection on both opsin molecules. While most firefly species are nocturnal as adults, in the species studied here there have been four independent transitions to diurnal activity. Both opsins show molecular changes associated with the evolutionary transition from nocturnal to diurnal behavior, indicating that this substantial change in light environment (night to day) selects for changes in the visual pigments.

 

Changes in signal color and background light environment across nocturnal firefly species are not associated with selection on visual pigments. An examination of changes in opsin molecular sequences and changes in signal color or the habitat characteristics (especially with regard to changes in background light color) of nocturnal fireflies found no evidence of a correlation. This suggests that changes in signal color or the amount or color of background light, against which a light signal must be observed, do not select (strongly) for changes in the opsin molecule. This finding points to other molecules besides the opsin visual pigments that likely play a role in making the eye appropriately sensitive to the particular signal color in the background light environment.

 

Amino acid sites under selection in fireflies are also under selection in other insect species. Six molecular changes that were identified as under selection in fireflies were previously identified as under selection in other studies of butterflies and bees. This finding strongly suggests that these amino acid sites are functionally important sites across insects.

 

Within a widespread species, Photinus pyralis, there is little amino acid variation in either opsins or luciferase across populations. For opsins, this finding is consistent with the across-species finding of no association between changes in opsins and changes in signal color or background light environment. For luciferase, contrary to the prevailing view, this finding indicates that differences in emitted light color are not always caused by changes in the luciferase amino acid sequence. Instead, fireflies may regulate their light color using pH or pigments in the abdomen.

 

In Photinus pyralis, there is evidence of strong selection on luciferase across populations. Luciferase shows strong structuring across populations for genetic variation that does not result in changes in amino acid sequence, relative to other, random genetic markers from across the genome.
